audio_caption: A male speaker begins with a friendly greeting, introducing a discussion on why "Polaris doesn't move." He clarifies that Polaris does move, albeit subtly.  He mentions discussing heliocentric and galactic models. The speaker pauses before saying, "um..."

The audio clip features a single male speaker, providing information on the galaxy. He explains that our galaxy consists of hundreds of millions of stars, including our sun, and that all stars visible to the naked eye are from the Milky Way. He continues by describing that our sun and other stars rotate around the galactic center, while their relative positions remain mostly the same, although individual stars have some movement. Finally, he states that this movement is difficult to track without very precise equipment.

The clip begins with one male speaker explaining that Earth's rotational axis doesn't change, which causes seasons. He emphasizes the tilt is "directed to the polar star" or "near the polar star." He corrects himself, noting that the "celestial pole... doesn't change its orientation" much, saying "it almost doesn't change its orientation".

A male speaker explains that in December, the northern hemisphere is tilted away from the sun while the southern hemisphere is tilted towards it. He explains that this is why the northern hemisphere has winter and the southern hemisphere has summer. He continues that the opposite is true in June. The speaker clarifies that the tilt stays the same, but the earth's position in its orbit around the sun causes the difference. He adds that the rotational axis still points in the same direction in both summer and winter. The clip ends with the male speaker sighing.

The audio features a single male speaker, who starts explaining that there are two reasons why Polaris doesn't stay in the same place, attributing it to stars rotating around the galaxy's center and having their own movement. His tone is informative and slightly academic. He concludes that it takes a long time to see constellations shift, requiring precise instruments.

The audio features a single male speaker with an informative and somewhat academic tone discussing the reason Polaris does not stay in the exact same place, mentioning the rotation axis and a movement called precession. He explains that this movement causes the rotation axis to change its tilt, indicating that it's not always 23.3 degrees.

The audio begins with a male speaker discussing star trackers, indicating these devices might be observed with instruments accessible to amateur astronomers. He explains that star trackers need to be polar aligned and function by rotating 15 degrees per hour to compensate for Earth's rotation, allowing a camera to stay pointed at the same spot despite the planet's movement. The speaker notes polar alignment is necessary for this to work, which involves looking through a scope and pointing at the polar star, Polaris. He concludes by mentioning seeing something.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing polar alignment, emphasizing that simply pointing at a star isn't sufficient because the star "is not at the celestial pole." He explains that Polaris has a certain distance "from the celestial pole" or "Earth's rotational axis," speaking in a clear, informative tone.

A male speaker is describing the use of a crosshair to mark the celestial pole, and the ring around it that helps align the polar star, dependent on the time of day and year. He explains that the position needs to change as the Earth rotates 15 degrees per hour. He continues, stating that there is not just one ring, but multiple, and that they indicate the year. He ends by explaining that the polar star changes its distance to the celestial pole and that this changes as the Earth rotates around its axis.

The audio clip features a male speaker discussing polar alignment. He explains how apps can determine position and time, then find "the correct position of the northern star" or Polaris. His tone is informative.

The clip begins with one male speaker explaining that if you have polar aligned the star tracker exactly, you can make very long exposures with the camera to photograph very faint objects not visible to the naked eye. The tone is informative. He continues, noting you can catch more light from the same point in the sky to make objects visible. He concludes that this is one interesting aspect of astrophotography.

The clip begins with a man speaking in an explanatory tone, discussing the term "circumpolar stars" and their dependence on location. He explains that these stars rotate around a celestial pole, never dipping below the horizon. He further details how the number of constellations visible varies depending on one's proximity to the celestial pole, and explains that at the equator, one may see both celestial poles, but no circumpolar constellations, and that Northern hemisphere circumpolar constellations are not visible from the Southern hemisphere and vice versa.

The audio features a male speaker discussing "seasonal constellations," explaining that they depend on the seasons, and that at different points in Earth's orbit, certain stars are obscured by the sun's light. He emphasizes that the constellations visible half a year later are different, with the previously seen ones now obstructed by the sun or daylight. The clip ends with a brief musical tone.
The audio clip begins with a male speaker mentioning "there's also a difference," followed by an explanation contrasting a solar day and a sidereal day, spoken in a clear and informative tone.

The clip starts with a male speaker explaining the definition of a solar day, and describing it as the time span between the sun taking the same position on two consecutive days.  He continues, mentioning that the Earth's orbit around the sun causes a difference between a solar day and a sidereal day, which he then defines as Earth's rotation relative to the stars. He further explains that looking at the sky and seeing certain stars at a position, shows the same position the next day after 23 hours and 56 minutes, and due to that difference, every day has roughly 4 minutes of difference over 365 days, adding up to an additional rotation. He finishes by thanking the listener for watching and saying goodbye.
